posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked: working on a few personal projects over the offseason. the core concept may evolve, but i'll continue working on them. most will remain in the conceptual phase, though some will progress further. i'm currently researching a reaction wheel control system for Areial vehicles (rockets and planes). i've also had ideas for a mars rover-style project and some FRC-based initiatives. many of these will utilize Arduino control systems. i'll share updates on all my projects occasionally.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked: The text is: Update: Day One Reaction Wheel Project: Found numerous online resources on reaction wheel design, including materials from NASA and the MIT OpenCourseWare site (a fantastic resource, definitely worth exploring). The MIT Rocket Team website also provided valuable insights. A simple mass budget calculator was developed in Google Sheets, targeting an initial prototype weighing less than 500 grams. The project will utilize an Odrive S1 motor and a CAN Controller Area Network (CAN) to USB-C adapter. All components must fit within a 98mm (from Apogee Rockets) blue tube airframe powered by a high-energy 4-cell lithium polymer battery with the highest milliampere-hour (mAh) rating remaining in the weight budget. Links to additional resources or a weight budget chart can be shared upon request. For my current inquiry, I am seeking recommendations for CNC machining services similar to PCBWay, evaluating their effectiveness, and exploring alternative options. Specifically, I am interested in machining services for flywheels or reaction wheels, with potential consideration for 3D printing parts such as screws or metal components.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
stayed up until about 1am last night doing some initial CAD work got a technical drawing for the v1.0 flywheel or reaction wheel. all dimensions are in mm. discussed potential material choices considering density and rust resistance brass was chosen for its high density and durability against rust which affects MOI and total weight. will likely use brass for the flywheel.  

motor assembly includes a simple motor model with necessary holes and clearances. built in CAD decided to create detailed screw specifications to stay within weight budget serving as good practice for future projects. planning to calculate moment of inertia and torque requirements to determine appropriate battery size aiming for approximately 8 minutes of full-speed runtime.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked: 3d printed prototype is now complete. Going to hold off on moi for now and work more on the casing that will sit between it and the tube frame. IMG_7066 1920×1440 138 KB

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
Took a two-day break and continued working on the motor mount CAD today. I fixed some incorrect math in the weight budget and nearly completed the final CAD. The total weight is officially under 500 grams, excluding the airframe and wiring. Batteries alone are expected to account for approximately 99 grams, leaving room for additional weight from wiring and airframe components. Now, regarding your questions:

Are there any good 4S LiPOS options available in the 850-1200mAh range that you’ve used before? If not, are there any lightweight wires you or your team commonly use? Additionally, do you have any specific filament types that you particularly prefer? Lastly, is there any restriction on using PETG or PLA for the mounting bracket?

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked: Are there any weight savings to be had with CF filaments or do they add weight? I have access to quite a few bamboo printers and wonder if it’s worth the time and effort or if I should stick with PLA/PETG. A side note: I might consider outsourcing the 3D printed mount for some Onyx or similar if I think it’s worth it.

posts.name: Brandon M
posts.cooked: The team used the Bambu PPA-CF for several items on their bot, finding its herringbone gear particularly effective, holding up exceptionally well under shock compared to aluminum while being lighter. However, the setup is costly, with the roll nearing $200 for half a spool. The team utilized a Bambu X1E and Creality Ender 3 with heating. A significant drawback is the high expense involved.
